notes: Append-only log. For concurrent edits: each agent edits ONLY their own response line for the current round. Do not add/remove/reorder lines.

how_to_add_next_round: Copy the block from round_start(wk1_r1) through round_close(wk1_r1), paste at end, and change round_id to wk1_r2 (then wk1_r3...). Keep one JSON object per line.
how_agents_should_write: Agents should NOT paste multi-line text into JSON strings. Instead, paste full reply into the per-agent markdown file path (raw_full_path), then put a single-line summary in raw_compact and fill the arrays.

prompt: For this week’s broad sweep, what are the 5 acceptance criteria that best capture ‘Majesty feel’ + modern clarity? Keep it testable in 10 minutes.
Propose minimal data structures/APIs for hero intent + last decision + bounty attractiveness so we avoid cross-system coupling.
Review planned changes for determinism pitfalls; list required guardrails.
Give recommended default values/bands for bounty rewards, lair bounty cost, and early pressure so pacing feels alive but fair.
Define intent taxonomy + logging rules; ensure mock/no-llm parity; suggest where to compute intent.
Propose a minimal early-game pacing nudge that uses existing systems (bounties/lairs/spawner) and is deterministic.
Write UI copy and layout for hero intent/last decision and bounty responders/attractiveness; keep it readable and non-spammy.
Suggest ultra-light icons/shapes for bounty type + attractiveness tiers that remain readable over fog-of-war.
Identify likely hotspots from these changes and propose 1–2 low-effort mitigations.
Update smoke checklist to cover new features; propose 3 regression scenarios to add.
Propose one dev flag/command to spawn a deterministic test setup for bounties+intent to speed iteration.
Draft patch notes for Build A and Build B using the template; highlight 3 bullets per build plus known issues.

raw_compact: Defined thin, deterministic-friendly contracts for hero intent/last decision + bounty evaluation; implemented hero-side intent/decision snapshot plumbing; next up: bounty responders+attractiveness + engine wiring for UI/QA.
summary_bullets: Added thin contract dataclasses in game/sim for hero intent/decision and bounty evaluation.
Hero now exposes intent + last decision in a UI-friendly, safe-default way (works with no-LLM/mock).
Bounty side will expose responders count + deterministic attractiveness tier for clarity.
proposed_changes: Add game/sim/contracts.py with small dataclasses + to_dict helpers.
Standardize hero.intent + hero.last_decision + helper snapshot accessor.
Add bounty.responders + bounty.attractiveness_score/tier and a BountySystem metrics update function.
Wire bounty metrics update into engine update tick so HUD/UI can read stable fields.
acceptance_criteria: Selecting a hero shows non-empty intent; last decision shows action+reason+age or safe placeholder.
Each bounty shows responders count and low/med/high attractiveness tier computed deterministically.
No crashes in --no-llm and --provider mock paths; no new import cycles introduced.
risks: Perf regression if bounty metrics become O(N_heroes*N_bounties) (must stay O(H+B)).
UI/logic coupling if UI imports AI modules instead of reading hero/bounty fields.
Schema drift if future LLM decision logging diverges from HeroDecisionRecord fields.
dependencies: UI reads hero.get_intent_snapshot() (or hero.intent/hero.last_decision) and bounty responders/tier fields.
Engine tick calls BountySystem metrics update before HUD render.
QA smoke adds checks for intent present + bounty responders/tier populated without exceptions.
questions_back_to_pm: Should bounty attractiveness tier be global (same for all heroes) for Build A, or per-hero (distance/class-weighted)? Recommendation: global for Build A.
recommended_next_actions: Complete bounty responders + attractiveness implementation and expose fields on Bounty/BountySystem.
Add engine wiring to update bounty metrics once per tick.
Coordinate with UI agent to display intent/decision + responders/tier using only the contract fields.

proposed_interfaces_or_contracts: HeroDecisionRecord(action, reason, at_ms, context) with to_dict(age_ms).
BountyEvalSnapshot(bounty_id, responders, attractiveness_score, attractiveness_tier) and fields on Bounty for UI consumption.

raw_compact: Determinism review: keep FS-1/FS-2 logic free of wall-clock time and unseeded RNG; enforce sim-time/ticks, stable iteration, and add a determinism guard as a QA gate.
summary_bullets: FS-1/FS-2 are determinism-sensitive due to timestamps/“age” and any scoring/picking logic.
Primary risks: wall-clock time (pygame/time) and unseeded RNG (random.*) leaking into sim logic.
Require deterministic iteration/tie-breaking (no set-order dependence) for bounty scoring/selection.
Recommendation: enforce via a static determinism guard + run it in QA smoke as a release gate.
proposed_changes: Store decision timestamps as sim-time or tick (not wall-clock).
Compute bounty attractiveness deterministically (no RNG; no wall-clock; stable tie-breaks).
Add/run `python tools/determinism_guard.py` as a release gate (ideally via `tools/qa_smoke.py --quick`).
acceptance_criteria: Bounty attractiveness uses no `random.*` and no wall-clock time; tie-breaks are stable.
Hero last-decision “age” uses sim-time or tick; safe defaults when no decision exists.
`tools/qa_smoke.py --quick` (or equivalent) fails if determinism guard finds violations.
risks: Accidental `pygame.time.get_ticks()` / `time.time()` usage introduced while implementing “age since decision”.
Adding RNG noise to attractiveness/scoring causes replay/lockstep desync later.
Using sets/dicts in outcome-affecting ordering (e.g., picking responders/top bounty) introduces nondeterminism.
dependencies: Agent 3: define hero intent/decision records with sim-time or tick fields.
Agent 6: keep any variability deterministic (seeded RNG streams) and avoid wall-clock use.
Agent 11/12: include determinism gate in smoke tooling / CI-ish workflows.
questions_back_to_pm: Should the determinism guard be mandatory for single-profile smoke runs too, or only `--quick`?
Is it acceptable for UI-only age displays to use wall-clock, or do we want UI to also reflect sim-time for consistency?
recommended_next_actions: Agent 3/6 implement hero intent + last decision schema with tick/sim-time fields.
Agent 5/8 implement bounty responders/attractiveness with deterministic ordering and no RNG.
Agent 11/12 wire determinism guard into QA gates and document the command in the sprint DoD.

determinism_risks: Wall-clock time usage for “age since decision” (pygame ticks/time.time).
Unordered iteration (sets/dicts) affecting picks or scoring outcomes.
required_guardrails: Use sim-time/ticks for all sim timestamps and elapsed-time calculations.
Use seeded RNG streams only via `game.sim.determinism.get_rng(tag)` (and avoid RNG entirely for scoring when possible).
Ensure stable ordering/tie-breaks: never depend on set iteration; sort keys/ids before selection.
Avoid Python `hash()` for determinism; use stable hashing or explicit IDs.

raw_compact: Define UI copy/layout for hero intent + last decision (action/reason/age) and bounty responders + attractiveness (Low/Med/High), plus low-risk HUD help toggle + placement mode banner.
summary_bullets: Hero inspect: show Intent + Last decision (action/target/reason/age) with safe placeholder.
Bounty markers: show responders count and attractiveness tier (Low/Med/High).
HUD: toggleable help overlay and clear placement-mode banner to reduce control-list clutter.
All UI additions designed to be mock/no-LLM safe and non-spammy.
proposed_changes: Add hero panel lines: Intent and Last decision (with age; sim-time based).
Add bounty marker metadata: responders count and attractiveness tier (compact).
Add HUD help toggle (F3) to show/hide controls.
Add placement mode banner: "Placing: <Building> (LMB place, ESC cancel)".
Keep copy concise; truncate long reasoning; avoid per-frame heavy allocations.
acceptance_criteria: Selecting a hero shows Intent and Last decision; if none yet, shows neutral placeholder (no errors).
Last decision shows action + short reason + age (or omits age if unavailable) and stays within panel bounds.
Each bounty displays responders count (0..N) and attractiveness tier (Low/Med/High).
Works with LLM, mock, and no-LLM; no crashes when there are 0 heroes or 0 bounties.
No noticeable UI overlap/spam; help overlay is optional/toggleable.
risks: Intent labels may diverge from future standardized taxonomy; mitigate by mapping to the contract once Agent 3/6 land it.
Per-frame text/metrics could cause perf regressions if expanded; mitigate by keeping computations lightweight and capped.
Overlay clutter near bounties; mitigate by compact labels and using the help toggle rather than always-on walls of text.
dependencies: Agent 3: stable data contract for hero intent/last decision to replace UI-side inference later.
Agent 6: intent taxonomy + ensure LLM reason strings remain short/consistent.
Agent 9 (optional): tiny iconography/contrast guidance for attractiveness tiers over fog-of-war.
questions_back_to_pm: Should help overlay default ON (onboarding) or OFF (cleaner HUD) for Build A?
Should attractiveness be global (simple) or eventually align with AI scoring/class bias (still deterministic)?
Do we want to convert B to a placement mode (toggle, click to place, ESC cancel) to prevent misfires?
recommended_next_actions: When hero intent/last_decision contracts land, wire UI directly to those fields and remove UI inference.
Add hover tooltip/legend for bounty tiers (optional) and ensure readability over fog-of-war.
If misfires become common, implement bounty placement mode (B toggles, click places, ESC cancels).

ui_copy: Intent: <Idle | Moving | Engaging enemy | Pursuing bounty | Shopping | Returning to safety | Resting>
Placement banner: Placing: <Building> (LMB: place, ESC: cancel)
Help hint: F3: Help / Controls (F3 to hide)
ui_layout_rules: Keep always-on HUD minimal; put full controls behind a toggle.
Prefer persistent state labels (intent/banner) over repeated toast spam.
Truncate long reasoning; never overflow panels.
Use compact world-space bounty labels; avoid multi-line text on the map.
Tier color semantics: Low=gray, Med=gold, High=green; maintain contrast over fog-of-war.
ux_acceptance_criteria: Player can answer "what is this hero doing and why" by selecting a hero.
Bounties clearly show who is responding and how attractive they are.
All new UI degrades gracefully with missing data (no exceptions).
No new non-deterministic time sources for any sim-relevant display (use sim-time for age).

raw_compact: Delivered procedural, pixel-crisp bounty type + attractiveness tier icons (with readable plate) plus fog-of-war overlay readability rules; no PNG art required for Build A.
summary_bullets: Procedural pixel-crisp UI icons for bounty type + attractiveness tier (cached, no art dependency)
Composite badge includes backing plate + 1px outline for fog/terrain readability
Documented overlay readability rules for fog-of-war (value + outline + plate)
Reserved assets folder for future hand-drawn UI icons (optional)
proposed_changes: Use `game/graphics/ui_icons.py` for bounty overlay icons (type + tier + composite badge)
Display tier as 1/2/3 chevrons (low/med/high) and type as symbol (compass/swords/shield/reticle)
Ensure overlay uses backing plate + outline for readability under fog-of-war
acceptance_criteria: Bounty markers show type + tier (or composite badge) and remain readable on grass/path/water and under fog-of-war
No external PNG assets required to ship Build A
Icons are cached (no per-frame allocations from icon generation)
risks: Icons become illegible if drawn without backing plate on noisy terrain/fog
Icon scaling must be nearest-neighbor; smoothing will blur pixel shapes
Overuse of always-visible badges could add visual clutter at high bounty counts
dependencies: Agent 8 to place badges in-world UI and decide always-visible vs hover/selection
Agent 3/5/6 to define/compute attractiveness tiers (low/med/high) for UI feed
questions_back_to_pm: Confirm tier color language: blue/gold/orange (cool→warm) vs green/yellow/red
Confirm visibility policy: always-visible vs only on hover/selection to reduce clutter
Future-proofing: should iconography emphasize action (sword/shield/compass) or target (lair/building/enemy) as more bounty types appear?
recommended_next_actions: Agent 8 integrate `get_bounty_badge()` into bounty overlay rendering and/or tooltip panel
After attractiveness tiers land, wire tier strings into badges (low/med/high)
Optionally replace procedural icons with hand-drawn PNGs later without changing UI contract

asset_suggestions: Optional future PNGs can live under `assets/sprites/ui/` at 16x16 or 20x20
readability_rules: Use a small dark translucent plate behind icons/text for contrast
Use 1px near-black outline around light shapes
Prefer shapes over text at small sizes; prioritize value contrast over hue
Avoid smoothed scaling; keep icons aligned to the pixel grid

raw_compact: Shipped low-risk perf guardrails: cached perf overlay + loop timing EMA, plus headless ms/tick benchmark and a short perf sanity checklist.
summary_bullets: Existing PF stats were already wired via navigation; biggest risks are PF thrash and per-frame UI allocations.
Perf overlay now avoids per-frame Surface allocation and shows loop timing EMA (events/update/render).
Added headless benchmark to measure ms/tick breakdown and PF stats; can output CSV for trend tracking.
Added sprint perf sanity checklist focusing on UI allocations and cross-product scan caps.
proposed_changes: Cache perf overlay panel and refresh on cadence/value change (avoid per-frame allocations).
Add loop timing instrumentation (events/update/render) using perf_counter; display as EMA.
Add headless perf benchmark runner to measure ms/tick and PF counters; optional CSV output.
Add perf sanity checklist doc for wk1.
acceptance_criteria: Perf overlay does not allocate a new panel surface every frame (cached + periodic refresh).
Overlay shows stable loop timing readout (events/update/render) plus PF counters without crashing.
Headless benchmark runs and prints ms/tick summary + breakdown + PF stats; optional CSV append works.
risks: Headless benchmark excludes render/fog cost; treat results as sim baseline only.
Future bounty attractiveness/responder logic could introduce O(N_heroes*N_bounties) per-tick scans if not cadenced/capped.
If overlay strings are expanded heavily, panel rebuild cadence may need adjustment to avoid text churn.
dependencies: Agent 8: ensure new hero/bounty UI caches text/surfaces and avoids per-frame allocations.
Agent 3/6: ensure intent/decision/bounty scoring is lightweight and cadenced; avoid heavy per-tick recomputation.
questions_back_to_pm: Do we want an explicit Build B perf budget target (ms/tick or FPS) tied to a standard scenario + reference machine?
recommended_next_actions: Add a perf step to release checklist: run 2–3 standard benchmark profiles and record outputs.
Once bounty responders/attractiveness lands, extend headless benchmark to include bounties and measure scoring cost.
Encourage UI changes to follow ‘refresh on cadence’ pattern to avoid per-frame text/surface churn.

hotspots: Pathfinding/navigation replans (A*) under higher entity counts or ‘pursue bounty’ behaviors
Cross-product scans (heroes x bounties) if computed every tick
Enemy/hero replanning churn when targets change frequently
mitigations: Cache and cadenced-refresh perf overlay panel; avoid per-frame Surface allocations
Instrument loop timings via perf_counter with EMA smoothing to spot spikes quickly
Use headless benchmark runner to measure ms/tick breakdown and PF counters; gate regressions
Recommend cadencing/capping bounty scoring to avoid O(N*M) per-tick
perf_acceptance_criteria: Overlay panel cached; rebuild on cadence/value change only
PF counters visible; loop timing EMA visible (events/update/render)
Headless perf benchmark executes and reports ms/tick + PF stats
